15.76. a) If Θ is a variety of groups, then let Θ0 denote the category of all free groups of finite rank in Θ. It is proved (G. Mashevitzky, B. Plotkin, E. Plotkin J. Algebra, 282 (2004), 490–512) that if Θ is the variety of all groups, then every automorphism of the category Θ0 is an inner one. The same is true if Θ is the variety of all abelian groups. Is this true for the variety of nilpotent groups of class 2?
An automorphism φ of a category is called inner if it is isomorphic to the identity automorphism. Let s : 1 → φ be a function defining this isomorphism. Then for every object A we have an isomorphism sA : A → φ(A) and for any morphism of objects µ : A → B we have φ(µ) = sBµs−1_A.
B. I. Plotkin
answer: Yes, it is, even for the variety of nilpotent groups of any class n (A. Tsurkov, Int. J. Algebra Comput., 17 (2007), 1273–1281).
